bookCover.coverDescription:
Welcome to Compass, this is all generating awareness of the amazing range of technologies that are available to all students in DCU. The technologies range from tools within your:

  • DCU Goggle student account

  • DCU Microsoft account

  • A tool called Sensus Access

  • and services that impart technology skills to you.

Compass is all about supporting you to navigate these technologies and services so you can settle into your student journey. We'll give you tips about how these DCU technologies can help with:

  • different ways to use technology for reading

  • choices about how you can write an essay with technology

  • Ways to use technology to stay organised.

  • Signposting you to technology-linked services so you can get help and technology skills.

params.text:
Your Microsoft account

All staff and learners in ETBs have access to Microsoft tools. These include Word, PowerPoint, Excel and more.

Once you have your ETB or college email, you can access your Microsoft account.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

This guide was adapted with permission from Compass, created by Trevor Boland and DCU.

Microsoft Account

Top tip - to download Microsoft programs go to the office website. Make sure you use your ETB or college email and password.

When you enter the Office website, you'll find a button called 'Install Apps' on the right of the site.

Select the 'Install Apps' button and and this reveals a new button called 'Microsoft 365 Apps'.

This downloads a file that when selected begins a process to install your Microsoft account.

params.title: begin to install be selecting 'Install Apps'.

params.text:
Install all your Microsoft software to your Laptop and Computer.

Note: Just remember, there are also Microsoft apps for your smart phones and devices. Just go your app store and download them, them sign in to them with your ETB or college email and password.

params.text: Start exploring how Inclusive Technology in your Microsoft apps, tools and applications can give you choice about how you do your day to day tasks. We are a diverse community so we need, and have, diverse technologies that support us.

hotspots.header: A video about your Microsoft account

params.text:
Online Microsoft account

Did you know that, as ETB staff and learners, that you have an online Microsoft account. Just go to the Office website and login with your ETB or college email and password to access it. It has all your applications like Word, PowerPoint, Excel and more.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Take some time to explore your online Microsoft account (It does need internet connectivity). Just open your browser, Chrome for example, log into Office with your ETB or college email and password.

A few examples of how it can be useful can be:

  • You can open up your files online like Word and PowerPoint
  • You can edit your files
  • Your work is saved automatically

Word, for example has a few tools that work rally well online. These include:

  1. Immersive Reader - it reads out loud your documents.
  2. Dictation - you can type with your voice instead of your hands.

params.alt: options in my onlince microsoft account like word, powerpoint and so on.
params.title: In my online microsoft account

params.text:
Explore all the options you have in your online Microsoft account. There is no save button as everything saves automatically as long as you have internet access.

Later we will explore options in Word online like:

  • Immersive Reader that reads out your Word Documents
  • Dictation that allows you to type with your Voice
  • Transcribe, that allows you to transcribe a recording of an interview into text

To name but a few.

params.text:
It is really easy to access your online Microsoft account.

It is really useful to explore as it is another way to write and save your assignments in DCU.

Tips about Word

Word is a dynamic application so it is good to spend some time to explore it's possibilities.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Possibilities of Word include:

  1. Enable Dark mode
  2. Turn Word document into interactive web page
  3. Convert photo or text PDF into editable Word document
  4. Copy and paste multiple items on clipboard
  5. Use formulas to calculate values
  6. Collaborate with others and @ mentions
  7. Rewrite suggestions
  8. Table of contents
  9. Citations and bibliography

params.title: how to find the dark mode option

params.text: Try dark mode in Word - does it make reading easier?

hotspots.header: Dark Mode in Word for easy reading

params.text: Word in a nutshell, it does a lot. Take time to explore you will find something new about it.

Reading Support in Microsoft

Immersive Reader is a reading support tool that can be found across the Microsoft applications. You can find it easily in Word and it reads out your text and does a whole lot more.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Immersive Reader

This provides options for a comfortable reading experience by allowing you to listen to the text read aloud or adjust how text appears by modifying spacing, color and more.

Your Word online has the most options when it comes to Immersive Reader. To find it, go to:

  1. Select the 'View' tab,
  2. then select 'Immersive Reader.'

Your document will open in a full screen format. 

Its key feature is the Play button that reads back your text - useful for proofreading.

Find out more in the Microsoft Website.

params.alt: The reading option in Immersive Reader.
params.title: Reading support in Word

params.text:
The reading option in Immersive Reader. You have options like:

  1. The reading speed so it can read faster or slower.
  2. Changing the voice from male to female.

Take time to adjust the settings so you can listen comfortably for a long time.

  • You can also change the text style and font and text size. (in the 'Aa' icon)
  • You can identify the grammar structure (in the 'Wand' icon)
  • You can also lessen distrations using line focus (in the 'Book' icon)

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Immersive Reader can help with:

  1. Proofreading your written work
  2. Support your understanding of information by listening and reading it.
  3. Supports memorization as you can listen to it as you read along.
  4. Improve the readability of information by changing the colour of the background of the document.

Dictation - Type with your Voice.

In Word, there is a tool available in Word called ‘Dictate’. This dictation tool gives you the opportunity to type with your voice instead of your hands.

Office 365 can is available to ETB staff and learners. Just go to Office.com and log into your Microsoft account with your ETB or college email and password.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Be patient with yourself when you try this for the first time. Dictation takes practice but it does pay off – best to read out paragraphs from a book to get familiar with hearing your voice and seeing the typed text appearing on the screen. 

Try to speak out punctuation in Word like ‘full stop’, ‘comma’, ‘new line’, and ‘delete’.

When you use the dictation tool for the first time, there are a few simply tips.

Trying reading out text from a book instead of saying text on the fly. Sometimes people are more confident reading out text in front of them.

Remember, your aim is to get you familiar with dictation and for Word to get familiar with your voice too.

params.text:
Dictation Tool

Top Tip: If you have handwritten your assignment, use dictation to help you create your typed version in Word. A big time saver.

Office Lens - An app for reading out text in a photo

There is an app available called ‘Lens’ and it is ideal for taking clear photos of documents and whiteboards. It has a specific feature called Optical Character Recognition (OCR) that converts the image of text into a text rich format, like clickable text in a document, and converts it into a Word Document. It also reads out the text in an image via the Immersive Reader tool. 

Most useful for: A useful way to gather photos for academic and work purposes as well as save them in PDF, Word or to use this OCR function so the text can be read aloud. 

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Office Lens has a few key features : 

  • Lens can take photos and clean up the images using filters. 
  • Lens can save handwritten text or a photo of text and save them in a Word format as it was written in a Word document – Check for spelling issues as mistakes may happen during this conversion. 
  • Lens can read out text that is in photos when using the immersive reader option - tap the play button as seen in the image.

Download the app to your Smartphone and try it.

params.alt: Office lens reads out text in a photo from a photo
params.title: Office lens reading out text

params.text:
Take time to explore the OCR tool in Lens and photograph text documents, save them in different formats and try out the filters to clean up the images and finally the OCR feature to convert a photo of text into a text rich format.

If you have a book, take a photo of the page, and use Lens to read it back to you. Take a clear and focused photo to get the best experience.

params.text: When you watch the video, think about the situations you may be in where you can photograph text and will need it read aloud. Will the library be a place you can photograph pages of text and then listen back to it (have your headphones on of course)

params.text:
Translate in Word

One of the many tasks Word can do is translation. It's not perfect so don't expect it to be complete;y accurate but it does have posssibilities. It has a large selection of languages and can read out the translation too.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Steps to Translate

Word online can translate with these steps:

  1. Select Review > Translate > Translate Document.

  2. Select your language to see the translation.

  3. Select Translate. A copy of the translated document will be opened in a separate window.

    Available in: 

Translation information from Microsoft.

Top tip - Immersive Reader has a translator tool also and it reads out the translated text in the chosen language.

params.title: go to review to find translate.

params.text: Try Translator - open a Word document that has text and translate it. Also Immersive Reader can Translate too.

params.text: Translator is not completely accurate but useful to translate written pieces to help your academic work.

Transcribing in Word

Another amazing tool in Word. Transcribing can be particularly useful when you are conducting interviews. In Word you can transcribe live or upload a recording into Word. This could be useful if you need a transcript of an intervied for your reserch.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

1. Make sure you're signed into Microsoft 365, in either Microsoft Edge or Chrome.
  2. Go to Home > Dictate > Transcribe.
  3. In the Transcribe pane, select Start recording.
  4. Wait for the pause icon to be outlined in blue and the timestamp to start incrementing to let you know that recording has begun.

params.alt: Go to the home tab, then go to Dictate, there is a small arrow below it, then select Transcribe.
params.title: Go to the home tab, then go to Dictate, there is a small arrow below it, then select Transcribe.

params.text:
Finding the Transcribe tool in Word

Go to the home tab, then go to Dictate, there is a small arrow below it, then select Transcribe.

Try it out before you use it on a participant. See the options it offers and which ones are relevant to you.

Also, test the accuracy too - a good microphone makes a big difference.

hotspots.header: Finding the Transcribe Tool in Word

It doesn't get all the words perfect so time for editing is needed.

metadata.title: Tell me all about Transcribe in Word.

params.text:
Editor - Spelling and Grammar

Whatever type of assignment we are creating we call do with spelling and grammar support. In Microsoft, we have a tool called Editor.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Editor in Microsoft

A Spelling and Grammar tool in Word can be found in the 'Review' tab. It gives you rich feedback on your writing.

Not only can it be found in Word, but it can be added to your browser too to help you with spelling and grammar in a webpage, blog or email for example.

Add Editor to your Chrome browser.

Add Editor to your Edge browser.

params.alt: Go to the 'Review' tab to find Editor.
params.title: Go to the 'Review' tab to find Editor.

params.text: Editor gives you rich feedback about your spelling and grammar. Take time to go through the feedback and decide if you should accept or not accept the recommendation.

hotspots.header: Finding Editor in Word - go to 'Review' tab

params.text: Get to know how you can use Editor to help your written work.

Word Document into a PowerPoint.

Sometimes you may want to plan out your presentation - especially for group work. Why not plan your presentation out it a Word document and with just a few clicks you can change it into a PowerPoint.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Export a Word document to PowerPoint

  1. Open the document you want to transform into a presentation in Word for the web. Make sure that it contains only text. The headings in the document will become the slide headings in the presentation.

  2. Go to File > Export > Export to PowerPoint presentation.

  3. In the Export to presentation window, choose a design theme for your presentation, and then select Export.

  4. In the Export to presentation window, choose a design theme for your presentation, and then select Export.

  5. After the transformation is complete, select Open presentation to review the results in PowerPoint for the web.

params.alt: Home then Export then the powerpoint option
params.title: Export the Word doc as a PowerPoint

params.text: Tip: Use bullet points in the Word document as this will inform the layout of text in your slides.

params.text: In just a few steps you can convert a well-planned Word document into a presentation.

OneNote for Note-Taking

Note-taking skills may be an essential part of the learning experience. In your Microsoft account, you have Onenote that offers amazing options for note-taking.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

OneNote for effective Digital Notetaking

Access OneNote on your computer or your smartphone and table devices.

This way you can access all your notes across all your devices if you use your ETB or college login details to log into each.

OneNote offers many features to aid in note-taking:

  • uploading files like PowerPoint and PDF into your notes
  • To-do lists
  • Add drawings
  • Add images
  • Handwriting if you have a device with a stylus.

• OneNote is a flexible digital Notebook that can be used in multiple way to stay organised. 

  • You can create multiple Notebooks on different topics. 

  • Within a OneNote notebook, you can take notes, type or write with a stylus, add drawings and photos, store links, and more. 

  • OneNote allows you to share notes or Notebooks with other people, so you can collaborate online. 

  • You can also add images from your camera or online, record audio and places in your notes, add pdf attachments to your notes and draw. 

  • You can also dictate your notes as seen in Word using the Dictation tool – this can be found in the ‘Home’ tab. 

  • You can have your notes read aloud using Immersive Reader in OneNote – this can be found in the ‘View’ tab.

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
• Explore the note-taking possibilities with OneNote. Find a method of note-taking that is tailored to your needs. Be patient and take time to find a way that feels right for you. These are a mix of possibilities with writing, images and audio recording, so it is worth discovering your preferred way to record notes.
  • If you find note-taking a challenge, then try supplementing your notes in OneNote, with images and audio recordings – please ensure you have permission to record audio and images in class.

PowerPoint – Closed Captions

PowerPoint allows you to present online in your browser. It is ideal for presenting, especially using the closed captions feature, to a group of people who can benefit from seeing your dialogue being converted into text in the presentation. Closed captions are text that is generated as you speak and displayed in your live presentation. 

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Switching on Closed Captions

  • On the Slide Show ribbon tab in PowerPoint, select Subtitle Settings. 

  • Use Spoken Language to see the voice languages that PowerPoint can recognise, and select the one you want. This is the language that you will be speaking while presenting. 

  • Use Subtitle Language to see which languages PowerPoint can display on-screen as captions or subtitles, and select the one you want. 

  • In the Subtitle Settings menu, set the desired position of the captions or subtitles. They can appear over the top or bottom margin of the slide (overlaid), or they can appear above the top or below the bottom of the slide (docked).

More appearance settings are available by clicking Subtitle Settings > More Settings (Windows). 

You can change the colour, size, transparency, and font style of the subtitles. You can change the background to improve contrast and make text easier to read.

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Top Tips: 

  • The quality of closed captions can vary for several reasons. These can include a poor microphone, a room with an echo, or if the presenter has a strong accent. 
  • Take time to try the closed captions feature – speak clearly and confidently and will help the accuracy of the captions. 
  • As good as the automatic live closed captions are, they are not as good as a captioner creating the captions live

Presentation Practice

Presenter Coach helps you give more effective in-person and virtual presentations by providing you with feedback on your word choice, and speed, among many others. Presenting is a skill that takes time and this tool offers assistance so you can practice your presentation and get useful feedback.

Most Useful for: exploring, experimenting and perfecting your presentation style and gleaning tips from the feedback that you can consider to improve your presentation skills. 

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

How to use Presenter Coach?

  1. Open your presentation in PowerPoint for the web.

  2. Sign into your ETB or college Microsoft 365 work or school account.

  3. On the Slide Show tab, select Rehearse with Coach. (If you've turned off the Simplified Ribbon, you don't have a Slide Show tab; instead use the View tab to start Presenter Coach.)

    The presentation opens in a full-screen view, similar to Slide Show.

  4. Select Get Started at the lower right when you are ready to begin rehearsing.

  5. As you speak, Coach gives on-screen guidance (in the lower-right corner of the window) about pacing, inclusive language, use of profanity, filler words, and whether you're reading the slide text.

  6. When you're through, exit the full-screen view. Coach opens a Rehearsal Report that summarizes what it observed, and offers recommendations.

Presenter Coach gives you feedback on may aspects of your presentation such as the pace of your presentation, the language use and if you repeats words.

Tip: To help prevent you from overusing the same words and phrases, Presenter Coach will identify them after listening to your rehearsal. Not only that, but it will also give you a list of synonyms that you can use instead so you can switch it up and keep your audience more engaged throughout your presentation.

params.text:
A few further tips

  • You need a microphone in your computer that can hear your speech and an internet connection.

  • We recommend that you rehearse in a quiet place with a microphone.

  • After you close the rehearsal report, it disappears. If you want to save a copy of it, you must take a screenshot.

Accessible Word Documents

As staff and learners, we can all do simple adjustments to make documents accessible to all. When we write with accessibility in mind, we create information that can be accessed by people with types of abilities. Let's make the world a little bit more inclusive.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

A good heading structure helps a screen reader user create a mental map of the content. You can use built-in header styles, available in Microsoft Word, instead of using colours to define your headings.  

To create accessible headings, follow the steps outlined below:  

  1. Home > Styles  
  2. Click on the style you want and then type your heading, or type your heading and then click on the style you want to use. 
  3. To verify that your headings create a good outline of the content, open the Navigation Pane and select "Headings" to browse the headings that are in your document. Select View > Outline to see how the headings will be organized.

Microsoft webpage about Accessibility

Heading Styles

Tip: Make sure your heading hierarchy makes sense.

Heading 1 style first, then heading style 2 and then 3 and so on.

params.text:
Accessible PowerPoints

As staff and learners, we can all make simple adjustments to make documents accessible to all. When we write with accessibility in mind, we create information that can be accessed by people with diverse types of abilities. Let's make the world a little bit more inclusive.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

Accessibility Tip - Headings

A good heading structure helps a screen reader user create a mental map of the content. You can use built-in header styles, available in Microsoft Word, instead of using colours to define your headings.  

To create accessible headings, follow the steps outlined below:  

  1. Home > Styles  
  2. Click on the style you want and then type your heading, or type your heading and then click on the style you want to use. 
  3. To verify that your headings create a good outline of the content, open the Navigation Pane and select "Headings" to browse the headings that are in your document. Select View > Outline to see how the headings will be organized.

Microsoft webpage about Accessibility

Heading Styles

Tip: Make sure your heading hierarchy makes sense.

Heading 1 style first, then heading style 2 and then 3 and so on.

params.text:
Accessibility Checkers

Microsoft Office has a built-in Accessibility Checker tool which finds accessibility issues and warnings, explains the reasons for them, and offers solutions.

Making your Word and PowerPoints accessible means that they can be used by all types of people with all types of abilities. Accessibility checkers help you to create inclusive files.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or image or video

In Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, select Review and choose Check Accessibility.

Types of issues that an accessibility checker can flag are:

  • Are headings present in the file - headings are key to break up information.
  • Colour contrast issues - low colour contrast can be challenging to see.
  • Do the images have alt-text - text within the image, so blind people know what the image is about.

This webpage by Microsoft has information about making your Microsoft files accessible.

It takes time to build up the habit of accessibility skills so be patient as you develop these. To perform an accessibility check use:

  1. Review tab.
  2. Check Accessibility button.

Note: Accessibility Checkers can pick up specific matters well like headings, alt text and colour contrast.

It can find it challenging to detect if a link has been added properly to text and if text is over complicated for the audience. Some checks must be done manually.

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Accessibility checkers vary slightly, as an example, Word and PowerPoint can bring up different matters.

Use YouTube to look for videos that can help you learn more about accessibility checkers and the types of issues they can detect and which issues they can't detect.

The more you get familiar with accessibility checking, the more aware you become of it and will develop strategies around it.
